customer.title: Customer Assumptions
customer.description: Who do you believe your users are and what do they care about?
prompts: Their primary motivation for solving this problem is...
They currently solve this problem by...
The current way they do things involves...
They are willing to pay because...
The size of this market is approximately...

problem.title: Problem Assumptions
problem.description: What problems do you assume are painful enough to solve?
prompts: The cost of not solving this is...
This problem is getting worse because...
Over the next 3-5 years, this problem will become more important because...

solution.title: Solution Assumptions
solution.description: What do you assume about how users would adopt your solution?
prompts: The key feature that matters most is...
Customers will switch from their current solution because...
Our pricing compared to alternatives is...

questions: Tell me about the last time you experienced [problem].
What have you tried in the past to solve this?
What's frustrating about your current approach?
If you had a magic wand, what would you change?
Walk me through the last time you tried to solve this problem.
What tools or products do you use today for this?
How much time/money do you spend on this currently?
What would happen if you didn't solve this problem?
Who else is involved in solving this problem?
How would you use a solution like this in your daily workflow?
What would make you switch from your current solution?
What's the most important thing it would need to do?
How would you know if it's working well for you?
What would make you stop using it?

dos: Ask about past behavior, not hypothetical future behavior
Ask follow-up questions to understand the 'why'
Take detailed notes during or immediately after
Thank them for their time and insights
donts: Don't pitch your solution during discovery
Don't ask what features they want
reminders: You're trying to understand their world, not sell them yours
Bad interviews are where you do all the talking
Good interviews leave you surprised by something you learned
The goal is to invalidate your assumptions, not confirm them
